title: The Red Room
author: Le Queux, William
snippet: Having lit a cigarette the doctor strolled down the Haymarket, and turning up Charles Street, passed the "Junior," crossed St. James's Square, where he entered the "Sports," made inquiry for someone, but found the person was hot in. Then, continuing his way--while I walked at a respectable distance behind--he turned into Duke Street, where at a door about half-way up he paused and tugged at a bell.

title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: This mean looking alley is the remains of a country road, along which some venerable citizens still remember to have wended their way between green hedges that skirted the pleasant meadows and corn fields of Wood's farm, and which was, in days of yore, a favourite trysting place for lovers, where they breathed out their tender tale of passion beneath the fragrant hawthorn. It led in an oblique direction towards the ancient village of Silvermills, and its course is still indicated by the irregular slant of the garden walls that separate the little plots behind Duke Street from the East Queen Street garden.

title: The life and correspondence of Andrew Combe ...
author: Combe, George
snippet: The continual clatter in riding almost prohibits conversation. We had heard much of the steepness of the streets, and the nearly precipitous roads out of town ; but in reality, most of the streets are only slightly inclined, and not more than three of them are steeper than Duke Street in Edinburgh. Portiotf of the roads are.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: On our arrival Fox wanted me to go and take a bed at his aunt's house, but Rogers having also invited me, could, of course, accept no other invitation. Went to my lodgings in Duke Street, which I found ready for me. Dined at the Athenaeum, and went early to bed.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: 1816. " My dear Moore, " I left my card In Duke Street, after receiving your first kind note. I intended to catch you there, if possible, some morning early ; but a world of unexpected and unpleasant business kept intercepting me day by day.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: He had plainly offered himself as a partner, and been gently shoved aside ; he now asked himself if he might not with all fairness try to constitute himself sole proprietor. Bryne's home was in Carruber's Close, and aster seeing him home, at a respectable distance, Loder sat down in a stair opposite to watch for his reappearance as patiently as Bryne himself had sat watching in Duke Street. It is the same all the world over—we are all sitting on steps watching for each other to make the next move.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: " It will brighten you up wonderfully," he said, " and restore bloom to your face, which is a terrible contrast to your clothing ! " Mrs. St. Clair handed him an envelope containing the requisite amount of bank notes. " Come, dear child," he said to Lucy; " I'll accompany you to Duke Street, and we'll settle scores with Mrs. Leslie," his face beaming with the pleasure of doing a benevolent action. Lucy then bade Mrs. St. Clair and Mrs. Dermot good-bye, promising to return on the third day after.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Many years ago, I got a proof of the unseen, and, therefore, unhelped miseries of the homeless dog. I was walking down Duke Street, when I felt myself gently nipped in the leg, — I turned, and there was a ragged little terrier crouching and abasing himself utterly, as if asking pardon for what he had done. He then stood up on end and begged as only these coaxing little ruffians can.

title: Memoirs of William Hazlitt.
author: Hazlitt, William Carew
snippet: Mr. Fisher was a poulterer in Duke Street, and Mr. Hazlitt met him at some Christmas party or Twelfth- Night celebration. There is a story too long to tell, and not sufficiently relevant either, to have a place in these pages, but it arose out of Mr. II.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: Francis and he might miss seeing each other on the very day the letter reached Great King Street if I sent it there; and then if he shouldn't be in town I'll write to Francis after." She tore up the first piece, asked Bella to put it in the fire, and wrote — " Mr. W. Williams will oblige by sending his address to L. Fairplay, 69, Duke Street, Northtown."

title: St. Ives;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Bryne kept Loder waiting much longer than he himself had been kept in Duke Street. It was after ten o'clock at night when he issued forth and descended the close.

title: Works of R. L. Stevenson. (Edinburgh edition.) [Edited by Sidney Colvin.]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Accordingly, being now quite recovered from my unmanly condition, except that nothing could yet induce me to cross the North Bridge, I arranged for my ball dress at a shop in Leith Street, where I was not served ill, cut out Rowley from his seclusion, and was ready along with him at the trysting-place, the corner of Duke Street and York Place, by a little after two. The University was represented in force: eleven persons, including ourselves, Byfield the aeronaut, and the tall lad, Forbes, whom I had met on the Sunday morning, bedewed with tallow, at the ' Hunters' Tryst.'

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: After passing Duke Street, High Street ascends with a

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: At length the gentlemen parted, and his task was less difficult, for he had only to follow the intending tourist, who, being alone, was not so apt to look round and notice that he was being tracked. The gentleman, indeed, went along with that buoyant step and cheerful aspect which every one has when grim work is for a time put behind and a pleasant tour before; and went as far as Duke Street without once alarming or disturbing Bryne. There he ascended a few steps and opened a stair door with a latch key, and disappeared within.
